column7: Stockland is one of Australia's largest diversified real estate groups, with $15.5 billion of real estate assets and a development pipeline of $40 billion.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column13: Stockland has an induction program for new Directors, including detailed briefings from management, meetings with external advisors and asset tours. It complements the existing program of site tours, topic deep dives, portfolio and strategy briefings presented to the Board under an annual program agreed upon with the Chairman.
column20: Induction program, external advisor, asset tour

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting

column13: The Board regularly assesses the independence of each director in light of the interests they have disclosed, and other factors the Board determines are appropriate. In FY23, each Non-Executive Director satisfied the requirements for independence.

Stockland's Conflict of Interest Policy monitors employee conflicts via a conflict of interest register. Conflicts are managed via an approved management plan. Conflict disclosures are reported to Stockland's leadership teams monthly, and a summary of material disclosures is provided to the Board Risk Committee at every meeting.
column20: Conflict of Interest Policy, conflict of interest register, management plan

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column13: The Board believes it has the right experience and skills to oversee the high standards of corporate governance, integrity, and accountability required of a professional and ethical organisation, as shown in the Skills Matrix diagram. Stockland is committed to having a Board whose members can act independently of management and have the collective skills and diversity of experience necessary to optimise Stockland's long-term financial performance to deliver long-term sustainable returns to securityholders.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column13: The Board has a process for regularly evaluating its performance, with an external review undertaken every three years and internal feedback provided annually between each external survey. In FY23, the Board undertook an external performance review with feedback from the review provided to the Board and individual directors.

column7: "Stockland has a clear strategy and a unique set of strengths and capabilities that position the group for continued success: a high quality, resilient portfolio; a strong, innovative, and customer-centric culture with a focus on safety; a commitment to ESG leadership supported by a proud record of achievement; brand leadership; multi-sector end-to-end capability across a large, nationallydiversified land bank; and a robust balance sheet. Our purpose, 'a better way to live', has driven us for the last 71 years, and our values of Community, Accountability, Respect and Excellence remain at the core of everything we do."

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: Stockland encourages employees and external stakeholders to report any improper conduct they encounter. All complaints are investigated fairly and objectively, including the involvement of external parties where appropriate. Those wishing to report improper conduct anonymously can do so via the 'Tell Me' online form or Stockland's external and independent whistleblowing service provider.
column20: Tell Me, improper conduct, whistleblowing service

column13: Stockland developed a group-wide Environmental Management System (EMS), which provides an overview of its commitment to environmental aspects and sets out how Stockland resources and implements programs and procedures to achieve its goals. The document has been structured around the international ISO 14001:2015 Environmental Management Systems to show how Stockland's initiatives align with the standard's requirements.
column20: Environmental Management System, environmental aspect, ISO 14001:2015

column7: Stockland adheres to Green Star and NABERS.

column13: Stockland's annual Liveability Index Survey measures what matters to its residents and helps inform its design and development processes, including strategic planning, placemaking guidelines, sustainability initiatives, and partnerships. This year, Stockland enhanced the survey to address feedback from residents and better reflect its diversified portfolio. It included streamlining the survey, including advanced analytics to identify drivers and opportunities of liveability better and extending the survey to include Halcyon homeowners.
column20: Liveability Index Survey, development process, strategic planning

column13: Stockland's Workplace and Logistics Satisfaction monitor takes the pulse of its tenants annually, allowing them to provide feedback on their relationship with Stockland. The insight from this research enables Stockland to address tenant pain points and identify future opportunities for improvement.
column20: Workplace and Logistics Satisfaction, tenant, future opportunity
